data.title: Oliver Wallscheid on LinkedIn: Thanks for having me in Vicenza
data.meta_description:
Thanks for having me in Vicenza / Padua Fabio Tinazzi! 

It was a pleasure delivering the guest lecture and also to learn more about the current research areas…
data.text:
Join us in the last seminar of the 𝗣𝗜 𝗦𝗧𝗢𝗥𝗜𝗘𝗦 𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟰 series organised by our UniTrento - IECS Doctoral School, aimed at providing the opportunity to learn the success stories of some of the most talented researchers in the world. 📅 June 27th at 1:00 pm, room Garda, Polo Ferrari 1 🎤𝗘𝗥𝗖 𝗥𝗼𝗯𝗼𝗳𝗹𝘂𝗶𝗱: 𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘄𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗼𝘁𝘀 𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗱𝗶𝗴𝗶𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗳𝗹𝘂𝗶𝗱𝗶𝗰𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗲𝗻𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘀𝘂𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁 𝗵𝘂𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗲𝘀 🗣 Vito Cacucciolo, Politecnico di Bari and Massachusetts Institute of Technology In this seminar, Vito will talk about his ERC project #Robofluid that aims at making fluidics digital using solid-state soft pumps. The ability to move fluids directly using electric fields will enable a range of wearable applications such as thermally regulated vests, haptic gloves, textile exoskeletons. 🌐Open to PhD Students, Bachelor and Master students enrolled at UniTrento DISI as well as to people interested in the topic. More Info 👇 🔗Seminar https://lnkd.in/eBt8TUUx 🔗Registration https://lnkd.in/eZrfFGxq #PI #PIstories #lifeasPI #seminarseries #stories #project #ideas #PhD #IECS #doctoral #ERC #robofluid #wearablesoftrobots #digitalfluidics #portabledevices #disi_unitrento #unitrento Giovanni Iacca

INESC MN integrates European consortium in innovative project between spintronics and artificial intelligence INESC MN, a research unit of Instituto Superior Técnico, is one of the partners in the European project "MultiSpin.AI: n-ary spintronics-based edge computing co-processor for artificial intelligence", which has secured funding of over €3M from the European Innovation Council (EIC) through the Pathfinder Open program (https://lnkd.in/drUdU8ew). The project started in February 2024 and will last for 3 years. The research consortium, led by Prof. Lior Klein from the Department of Physics at Bar-Ilan University, brings together researchers from INESC-MN (Portugal), Bar-Ilan University (Israel), and UCLouvain - Université catholique de Louvain (Belgium), as well as industrial partners such as SpinEdge LLC (Israel) and Interactive Fully Electrical Vehicles (Italy). In Lisbon, the team is led by Prof.Susana Freitas, a researcher at INESC MN and professor at the Department of Physics of Instituto Superior Técnico, whose widely distinguished work in thin films and spintronics will be essential for the design and manufacturing of magnetic nanodevices in the project. The Pathfinder Open program promotes high-risk, high-reward scientific innovations and the development of technologies still in the early stages. This is the case of the innovative device that the project proposes to develop, applying spintronics to the field of artificial intelligence: processing units based on magnetic tunnel junctions that exhibit multiple distinguishable magnetic states, allowing for more than the usual 2 digital states and, therefore, achieving significant gains in terms of computing speed and energy efficiency. This hardware will be integrated into information processing through neuromorphic computing. The impact will be significant in artificial intelligence applications that require high energy consumption and increased computational resources, thus benefiting from the optimization of processing capacity (for example, in areas that require "on-site" computing, such as autonomous mobility or robotics). With the project, the development of an initial prototype and the demonstration of the proof of concept are expected, through the integration of magnetic devices into a processing array and the construction of artificial intelligence algorithms that validate it. #WeareTécnico #AI #innovation #spintronics #PathfinderOpenProgram #research #EIC #INESCMN

Aston University Receives £1 Million Grant to Revolutionize Miniaturized Optics for Manufacturing, IT, and Agriculture Aston University is leading the way in miniaturized optics with a £1.17 million grant to develop revolutionary devices for various industries. The project, titled Picometer Surface Nanoscale Axial Photonics (PicoSNAP), is helmed by Professor Misha Sumetsky of Aston University's Institute of Photonic Technologies (AIPT). It aims to overcome limitations in traditional fabrication by creating devices a million times smaller than a human hair (measured in picometers). PicoSNAP technology offers unique light manipulation capabilities: Light travels along the fiber's perimeter, enabling functionalities not possible with conventional methods. This breakthrough has the potential to: > Deliver miniaturized optical devices with unprecedented performance > Revolutionize fields like manufacturing, IT, and agriculture with highly precise sensors The project will focus on developing a scalable and reliable manufacturing process for these picometer-scale devices, paving the way for real-world applications. This research aligns perfectly with Aston University's commitment to impactful research addressing global challenges. https://lnkd.in/dEr39aYk #optics #photonics #nanotechnology #engineering #research #astonuniversity #PhotonicSpots #PhotonicsTimes

Academic Update! Recently, I successfully presented my M. Tech minor project, which focused on highly stretchable soft sensor for soft robotic wearable devices, aimed at human motion and health monitoring. This experience was challenging yet rewarding as it marked my first presentation of this kind. I am deeply grateful to Dr. Soumen Sen, Dr. SOUMEN MANDAL, and Dr. Nripen Chanda (Human Centred Robotics & cybernetics Group) for their unwavering support, meticulous monitoring, thorough technical evaluation, and invaluable guidance throughout this project. Their expertise and encouragement have been instrumental in shaping my master's research journey. I am now eager to connect and enthusiastic to explore with researchers worldwide who share similar interests and expertise in this field. Thank you for any sharing or connections provided. CSIR-Central Mechanical Engineering Research Institute (CMERI) Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research #SoftRobotics #WearableRobotics #AssistiveWearableDevices #stetchablesensor #flexiblesensor #Sensor #HumanMotionMonitoring #SoftSensors #StretchableSensors #SoftActuators #BiomechanicalAnalysis #HumanRobotInteraction #RehabilitationRobotics #HealthcareTechnology #BiomedicalEngineering #eskin #SmartMaterials #SensorIntegration #MachineLearning #ArtificialIntelligence #TechnologicalInnovation #ResearchCollaboration #AcademicNetworking #GlobalResearchCommunity #IITDelhiResearch #CSIRCMERI #AcademicExcellence #InnovationInRobotics #InterdisciplinaryResearch

A new development by researchers at the Faculty of Engineering at Tel Aviv University will help identify small drones in challenging scenarios, such as urban environments, low flight altitudes, and extreme weather conditions, enhancing the protection of airspaces via smart tagging. The research team notes that drone identification is generally conducted using radars, cameras, and transponders, with the latter providing real-time updates on location in civilian contexts. However, these methods can fail in harsh conditions, including limited line of sight, multiple air traffic participants, and tall buildings blocking satellite signals, among other challenges. The researchers highlight that this new technology can overcome these challenges and provide a superior level of reliability by using smart stickers and a radar supported by an AI algorithm that classifies drones based on the electromagnetic radiation they scatter. The development was led by Ph.D. students Omer Tzidki and Dmytro Vovchuk from Prof. Pavel Ginzburg’s lab, the Iby and Aladar Fleischman Faculty of Engineering. The lab specializes in developing novel radar and wireless communication technologies, facing new and forthcoming challenges. Read more: https://lnkd.in/ehnfM7_r #SmartTagging #TAUResearch #DroneIdentification #AI #NewTechnology #engineering The Lowy International School, Tel Aviv University Tel Aviv University Alumni Organization The Faculty of Engineering Tel Aviv University Tel Aviv University Engineering Alumni Department of Physical Electronics -Faculty of Engineering, Tel Aviv University

Pioneering Innovation @ #CU: Research Endeavors and Excellence Centres Research scholars, Students and Faculty members, let's harness these cutting-edge facilities and accomplishments to elevate our research pursuits. Together, the CU isn't just creating knowledge; it's shaping the future. At #CU, research isn't just part of the curriculum; it's the essence of our academic ethos. Guided by visionary leadership, we stand as India's leading research-intensive university. 🌟 Cutting-Edge Facilities: State-of-the-Art Labs: FMS Lab, XRD Lab, Genetics Lab foster breakthroughs. 🌟 Diverse Research Domains: #CUResearchDomains · Multi-disciplinary Approach: IT, Healthcare, Additive Manufacturing, Agriculture, Robotics & Automation. 🌟 Student-Led Innovations: #InnovationLeadership · Ingenious Projects: Driverless cars, CanSat, sounding rockets showcase student ingenuity. 🌟 Elevating Research & Innovation: #CUKalpanaChawlaCentre · Kalpana Chawla Centre: Dedicated hub for space research. · DGCA Approved Drone Training Hub: Leading in UAV technology. · Centers of Excellence: Indigenous Processor Development, Geoinformatics, Happiness Science, Automobile Engineering, and more. 🌟 Leaders in Innovation: #ResearchExcellence · Pioneering Patents: Leading in #innovation with the highest patents filed in India · Impressive Achievements: 2000+ patents, 11,000+ research publications, 75+ Department Research Groups These achievements, a testament to CU's commitment to excellence in research and innovation, wouldn't be possible without the collective effort of the CU community. Special gratitude to our #CU's visionary leaders for steering us towards becoming a landmark institution in research and development. #ChandigarhUniversity #CUAchievements #LeadershipExcellence

Big shoutout to Fabio Izzi from the Dynamic Locomotion Group for successfully defending his doctoral thesis! "During my PhD, I investigated how muscles stabilize rapid locomotion. Similar to how car suspensions smooth out a bumpy ride, muscles possess unique mechanical properties that support the stability of our movements and enable us to react fast when stepping on something unexpected. This research topic has important implications for neuroscience as it shows that our nervous system can exploit our body mechanics when dealing with complex locomotive tasks. Thanks to the interdisciplinary community at IMPRS-IS, I also collaborated with Dr. An Mo in integrating these biological concepts into the design of advanced legged robots. Getting my PhD was an exciting and emotional journey. I am immensely grateful for the extraordinary individuals I encountered at IMPRS-IS and Universitätsklinikum Tübingen. Their support, guidance, and friendship were pivotal to my success." Fabio began his academic journey in mechanical engineering at Politecnico di Milano. Upon completing his bachelor’s degree, he was admitted to TU Delft, where he studied Biomechanical Design and BioRobotics. For his master’s project, Fabio developed an algorithm that allows a lower limb exoskeleton to be controlled by the swing of a patient’s arm. In 2019, he began his doctorate at MPI-IS in the Dynamic Locomotion group under the supervision of Dr.Alexander Badri-Spröwitz and Dr. Daniel Häufle. Now, he moved to Boston to work as a postdoctoral researcher in Professor Song’s lab at Northeastern University. Fabio’s current endeavor involves customizing neuromusculoskeletal models to enhance the development and evaluation of wearable robotic devices. #MPIIS #IMPRSIS #IntelligentSystems #Phdstudent #Phdthesis #ThesisDefense

On October 18, Sang-woo Nam and Dong-ju Choi, students in the integrated master's/PhD program at DGIST’s Department of Robotics and Mechatronics Engineering, and members of Prof. Jae-Sok Yu and Prof. Sangyoon Han's joint research team, were selected as finalists at the IEEE International Ultrasonics Symposium 2023. Their paper was among the top 15 of over a thousand papers submitted to the symposium and described a new semiconductor-based ‘ultrasonic sensor’, which was created by the team by combining silicon-photonics and micro-electromechanical systems. The sensor is highly sensitive and can detect ultrasonic waves with extremely low intensities. The research was funded by the Samsung Future Technology Development Project and is expected to pave the way for futuristic, high-performance sensors in ultrasonic testing and medical ultrasound imaging. Read more here: https://ow.ly/6HI450QaaMX #DGIST #ScienceandTechnology #University #Photonics #UltrasonicSensor #Semiconductor #MedicalImaging #Ultrasound #Samsung #Mechatronics #Robotics #IEEE
